Knowledge Point: Word order in Vamale does not change across clause types. Vamale is head-first and usually VOS, though fronted, bi-clausal constructions are common: S, VO. The verb always precedes the object, and the traditionally non-marked order expects the subject after the noun. Oblique arguments tend to follow objects (\ref{ex:obj_then_obl}), but pragmatic choices can invert the unmarked order (\ref{ex:obl_then_obj}). In general, the earlier a constituent is introduced, the more marked it is. %The subject is often fronted, but may then still occur after the verb, indicating that a fronted subject is not a constituent of the clause.\footnote{Prosodically, too, the fronted subject has an own contour, which yields two intonation units: the fronted subject, and the clause.} Fronting can be used to focus on any constituent, a resumptive morpheme remains in the matrix clause.
Content 1: \gll e=holeke [sikaa]\textsuperscript{obj} [nyasi i=apuli a= xhwata]\textsuperscript{obl} | \gls 1SG=thank.for cigarette BEN DEF.SG=man REL= bald | \glt I thank the bald man for the cigarette.
Content 2: \gll e=holeke nyasi-m li=fati a= go=vi | \gls 1SG=thank.for BEN-2SG.POSS DEF.PL=word REL= 2SG=say | \glt I thank you for the words.

Knowledge Point: The basic word order VOS is generally more common with older speakers, while younger generations often front the subject. Stative verbs, especially with inanimate arguments such as in (\ref{ex:xhong}), seem to be exempt from the fronting mentioned above, regardless of the speaker demographic. With animate arguments, fronting is especially common, especially when the agent is stressed. Strategies to make the subject less salient to the listener include using the VOS order, as well as not mentioning the subject, and fronting the object, as in (\ref{ex:fronted_obj}).
Content 1: \gll sinu i=xho-ng | \gls ill DEF.SG=leg-1SG.POSS | \glt My leg hurts.
Content 2: \gll go, e=xale-ko | \gls 2SG 1SG=see-2SG | \glt You, I see you.

Knowledge Point: %Stative verbs use different morphemes to mark their subjects, and those suffixes are not identical (although very similar) to object-marking suffixes found on transitive verbs, as in (\ref{ex:1sg_sbj}). Inanimate participants are neither marked with object suffixes nor stative subject suffixes, but otherwise behave like animate ones, i.e. inanimate noun phrases are flagged as subjects and obliques. Both non-specific objects (irrespective of animacy) and inanimate non-specific stative subjects are marked with -n \qu{\gl{nspec}} on the verb. This distributional similarity between inanimate objects and stative subjects, as well as the formal similarity of the -\gl{S\textsubscript{P}} and -\gl{p} suffixes raises questions concerning an animate/inanimate split.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Putting ka at the end of a sentence is a question to the listener: do you follow? This ka (\ref{ex:coorka1}) is probably related to ka \qu{\gl{cnj}}.
Content 1: \gll jaa nyu ka | \gls many fish DISC | \glt way too many fish, like

Knowledge Point: One of the most common morphemes found on a clausal level is go \qu{well, now, and then}. It cannot be used to coordinate noun phrases nor verb phrases, and occurs before coordinators, assertive tha, and other left-most boundaries of clauses (\ref{ex:go}). It is a frequent filler, stretched out to prolong the thinking time of the speaker (gooooo... \qu{weeell}). Its meaning does not carry information about the relationship of the surrounding clauses: while in many cases, the clause following go \qu{and then, furthermore} does semantically follow the previous ones (\ref{ex:go2}), go \qu{now, on the other hand} can also mark a change of subject.
Content 1: \gll go tha le=vwa goo i=coutume a= tha le=vwa | \gls DISC ASS 3PL=do enough DEF.SG=custom REL= ASS 3PL=do | \glt Well, they kept the ceremonies that they did, moderate.
Content 2: \gll go ka e=ilake hapi gavwe wago | \gls DISC CNJ 1SG=ask COMP 2PL brave | \glt Well, and I ask you to be brave.

Knowledge Point: Similarly to go, bwa is frequently used at the beginning of a clause. It contributes an attenuating meaning to the clause: \qu{just, first, quickly} (\ref{ex:bwa_disc}), but is also used like go to keep the speaker role (\ref{ex:bwa_disc2}).
Content 1: \gll bwa the-balan=wan-ea ka i=yata-n Manu ka | \gls DISC THEPUNCT-REAL=change-3SG.OBJ CNJ DEF.SG=name-3SG.POSS M. DISC | \glt First thing that was done, he was quickly and suddenly replaced by the one called Manu, you know.
Content 2: \gll ha-go bwaa, tha bwa devoilé Wawa mwa ka Jon xaleke | \gls EXCM-2SG DISC ASS IPFV unmasked W. DEICT SBJ J. see | \glt Man, well, that's when Wawa was unmasked by John, see.

Knowledge Point: Vamale has no copula, and thus juxtaposes two nouns do form an equative construction, where the first is the topic, and the second the comment. The example given in (\ref{ex:nyaiung}) is in Usa Vamale.

Knowledge Point: The nominal predicate can also be marked with a third person proclitic a (\ref{ex:xavee1}) and be followed by a subject NP flagged with ka \qu{\gl{sbj}} (\ref{ex:xavee}).

Knowledge Point: Content questions replace the missing information with a question word, though examples where the missing information is at the end, and just left out, are also attested. The question words are listed in \Cref{tab:ques}. The pronoun kai \qu{who}, maybe from ka i \qu{and the}, does not have cognates in neighboring languages.\footnote{Voh-Koné \parencite[125]{rivierre_bwatoo_2006} as well as Cèmuhî \parencite[215]{rivierre_langue_1980} use de.} The noun da \qu{what}, used to be considered a impolite, threat-like form, because of its homophony with da \qu{spear} (\ref{ex:da2}). hmwaeke \qu{how?} is preferred, as in (\ref{ex:ko_hmwaeke}). The adverb hmwa-eke \qu{how} is related to the verbs hmwa-ena/hmwa-ehni \qu{thus}, the noun hmwa-goon \qu{half} (probably composed of hmwa- and goo-n \qu{body, sum}), as well as the adverb hmwa-ka-n \qu{like X}. nyeet \qu{when} is an adverb (\ref{ex:nyeet}).

Content 2: \gll sahnaang-eo ma le=vwa ko hmwaeke | \gls not.understand-1SG SUBR 3PL=do because be.how | \glt I'm not sure why they do this (lit. I'm not sure that they do it because of what).
Content 3: \gll go=ta-mwa-me nyeet? | \gls 2SG=go.up-REP-DIR.CP when | \glt When did/will you come back?

Knowledge Point: The stative verbs heeve\qu{where (mobile)} (\ref{ex:heeve}) and ve\qu{where (immobile)} (\ref{ex:ve}) can be combined with nya \qu{towards} and eca \qu{\gl{indf}.\gl{pl}} to form adverbs.

Content 2: \gll go=ha-me moo ve? | \gls 2SG=go-DIR.CP stay where | \glt Where are you coming from?

Knowledge Point: Orders take two forms: The simple form, used in intimate settings and with younger people, in situations of emotional affect etc, is the same as the quotation form of verbs, and consists in the stem (\ref{ex:imp}). The person meant by the imperative can be marked by adding a noun phrase ka \qu{\gl{sbj}} + pronoun after the verb (subject indexing is still dropped) (\ref{ex:imp_PN}).
Content 1: \gll se! | \gls cry | \glt Cry!
Content 2: \gll xale-ke ka go! | \gls look-TR SBJ 2SG | \glt Look!

Knowledge Point: The other, more polite form is an (in)subordinated clause (\ref{ex:insub}), which may be joined by a main clause expressing the speaker's attitude towards the order: xahnang \qu{good}, juu aman \qu{important}, goon \qu{possible, permitted}, etc. This is discussed in further detail in \sectref{ssec:Insub}. This construction is the most commonly used for stative verbs, which rarely occur in imperative settings.
Content 1: \gll (xahnang) ma go=soom... | \gls (good) SUBR 2SG=swim | \glt You could swim (that would be good)

Knowledge Point: Prohibitive clauses, contrary to the imperative, admit person marking (\ref{ex:prohPN}), though this is rare; ka + PN constructions are preferred. Every prohibitive predicate is preceded by a dedicated particle cipii (\ref{ex:cipii}).\footnote{The prohibitive particle contains the negative prefix ci- (PMP *(q)ati, \citealt[88]{lynch_oceanic_2002}) also present in cika \qu{\gl{neg}.\gl{exist}} (from POc *tikai, \citealt[88]{lynch_oceanic_2002}), in cia- \qu{be absent}, and the neutral negator cipa.} Bwatoo uses cipa for both negating and prohibitive functions \parencite[58]{rivierre_bwatoo_2006}. %, but features cieden \qu{be absent} and cau \qu{\gl{neg}.\gl{exist}}.
Content 1: \gll go=cipii weke | \gls 2SG=PROH rage | \glt Don't be angry.
Content 2: \gll cipii see | \gls PROH cry | \glt Don't cry!

Knowledge Point: The assertive tha is a frequent particle on the far-left border of the predicate. Preceded, in subordinate clauses, by the subordinator (e.g. a \qu{\gl{rel}}, cama \qu{\gl{subr}}), and in equative constructions by the topic, tha is analyzed as belonging to the predicate both syntactically and phonologically. The particle expresses that the speaker is invested in the content, i.e. that they believe the thing to be true, and is thus in complementary distribution with (b)o \qu{\gl{irr}}. A notable exception, already discussed in \sectref{sec:bo}: if a formerly irrealis situation has been realized, the past situation can be marked as irrealis via bo and still spoken of with confidence (\ref{ex:tha_bo}). %Assertive markers are attested in other Northern languages tooExists in Bwatoo, might be cognate with the \gl{cntr} in Nelemwa?
Content 1: \gll e=caihnan hapi {tha} go={bo} vwa | \gls 1SG=know COMP ASS 2SG=IRR do | \glt I knew that you would do it.

Knowledge Point: Apart from tha, Vamale uses a variety fixed expressions to express speaker certainty concerning the discussed information. Doubt is expressed by using cama \qu{if, when (\gl{irr})} (\ref{ex:cama_mod}), bo \qu{\gl{irr}}, or with verbs like cacahniing- \qu{be unsure} and sahnaang- \qu{be confused, not know}. Certainty, a part from tha, is expressed by using realis TAM markers pa \qu{\gl{prf}} and ja \qu{\gl{prf}} (\ref{ex:ja_mod}). The particle for generally known truth ko described for western varieties \parencite[55]{rivierre_bwatoo_2006} is not attested in Vamale; instead vwa hâwan nyakoo-n \qu{there is a visible manifestation of it} is used (\ref{ex:vis_tru}).
Content 1: \gll cama fine nya-koo-n | \gls if count put-on-3SG | \glt It is doubtful. (lit. Whether one counts on it)
Content 2: \gll th=e ja fine nya-koo-n | \gls ASS=1SG count SUBR put-on-3SG | \glt I am sure of it/him/her.
Content 3: \gll vwa hâwân nya-ko hapi a=welo | \gls EXIST spirit put-on SUBR 3SG=crazy | \glt It is apparent that he is drunk [he is slow, slurred speech etc].

Knowledge Point: Vamale expresses deontic modality through subordinating constructions with ma \qu{\gl{subr}} (\ref{ex:modal_ma1}), further discussed in \sectref{ssec:ma}. The matrix clause is a single modal word and the subordinate one contains the Comment. Important constructions are goon ma... \qu{enough \gl{subr}} \qu{it is possible/allowed to...}, siteke ma \qu{taboo \gl{subr}} \qu{it is forbidden to...}, vwasoon ma \qu{impossible \gl{subr}} \qu{it is difficult/impossible to...}, xahnang ma \qu{good \gl{subr}} \qu{it is good to...}. The constructions may use cama \qu{if, when (\gl{irr})} instead of ma to express more hypothetical scenarios.
Content 1: \gll vwasoon {ma} le=fe-ta-ong ko-n salle vukin da | \gls impossible SUBR 3PL=take-go.up-1SG.OBJ OBL-NSPEC operation.room reason why | \glt They couldn't take me to the hospital because of what?

Knowledge Point: The particle mwa, already mentioned in \sectref{sec:WCRepetitive}, versatile and docks onto verb and noun phrases alike, as well as adverbs. This chapter takes it into closer consideration now rather than in previous parts, because mwa cannot be attribuated to one particular word class more than to another. It takes different, related meanings depending on the context (\ref{ex:daahma_mwa}).
Content 1: \gll i=daahma mwa | \gls DEF.SG=chief REP | \glt the chief again/too/even\\

Knowledge Point: The most common function is repetition, and its close cousin, restitutive \qu{back}. Other meanings conveyed by mwa include \qu{also}, \qu{even}, \qu{on top of that}, but mwa can also mark the preceding phrase as focused (see \sectref{sec:mwa} for a discussion). mwa \qu{now}, appears to mostly anchor the listener's attention, similarly to mwa \qu{even}, onto the noun phrase given (\ref{ex:mwa_now2}).
Content 1: \gll hâ gaa mwa naen hmwa-ena | \gls yes 1PL.INCL REP now be.like-DIST | \glt Yes, we (however) are like that now.

Knowledge Point: Consider (\ref{ex:mwa_repb}), which was already shown in \sectref{sec:WCRepetitive} to illustrate that mwa can dock onto verb and noun phrases alike. This example shall also serve to show how mwa's scope works: while nya si-m \qu{put hand-2\gl{sg}.\gl{poss}} is the unmarked construction meaning \qu{to give to you}, [nya mwa] si-m means that the object is handed down from a previous interaction (not with the present recipient): \qu{give again, to you}. However, nya si-m mwa means that something is given, as other things were given before, to the same recipient: \qu{give to you this as well}. This mwa can also mean that something is given here, now, even, etc. And finally, [[nya mwa] si-m mwa] can have several meanings: either something is handed back and forth between Source and Recipient several times \qu{give back to you again}, or only once (and the last mwa has a deictic function) \qu{give back to you now, give back to you as well}, or several Themes take the same (possibly reciprocal) Path: \qu{give this, too, to you} (22.07.2019, p.76). All of the above-mentioned constructions are attested, especially in customary exchange speeches.
Content 1: \gll e=vatipwe mwa nya mwa si-m mwa i=mwani mwa | \gls 1SG=drop REP put REP hand-2SG.POSS REP DEF.SG=money REP | \glt I pass on to you too this money as well.

Knowledge Point: In (\ref{ex:movV-mwa}) and for all other movement verbs, as well as xhose \qu{do again}, mwa is analyzed as suffix, i.e. as having fused phonologically with its host. Apart from integrating the host's stress contour, which mwa does with other words as well, mwa assimilates to the root, which it does not do in other contexts.\footnote{xhosepwa suggests a dropped -t or -p. The Pije and Fwâi cognates khô-peei \qu{?-say} \parencite[155]{haudricourt_dictionnaire_1982} could be a diachronic hint at a morphologically complex, old Vamale form.} Compare hut-mwa \rightarrow /hupʷa/ \qu{go back down}, to hut=mwa \qu{go down again}.

Knowledge Point: As such, mwa marks temporal and spatial immediacy to the speaker or the spoken-of event: in example (\ref{ex:temp_mwa}), mwa is used to connect the events tightly together, expressing how quickly things followed each other. In (\ref{ex:mwa_deict}), the noise referred to is already known to the speaker, because it was recently mentioned. In (\ref{ex:thathea_mwa}), mwa clarifies which event had happened by which moment in the narration: he had already died by the time they found him. Concerning spatial deixis in (\ref{ex:spat_mwa}), the area in question is visible from the speaker's chair. The semantic closeness to the deictic constructions discussed above is apparent: in both cases, mwa designates something known to the speaker and to the hearer.
